$$

Moreover, for the case where agent $i=1$ employs an arbitrary control law $u_{1} \in \mathcal{U}^{[N]}$, we have

$$
\begin{aligned}
x_{1}(t)-x^{[N]}(t)= & \int_{0}^{t} S(t-r) F_{1}\left(\bar{x}(r)-x^{(N)}(r)\right) d r+\int_{0}^{t} S(t-r) D\left(x_{1}(r)-x_{1}^{[N]}(r)\right) d W_{1}(r) \\
& +\int_{0}^{t} S(t-r) F_{2}\left(\bar{x}(r)-x^{(N)}(r)\right) d W_{1}(r)
\end{aligned}
$$

The rest of the proof for (4.80) and (4.82) follows the method used in Theorem 4.9 by taking square norms, expectation, applying Grönwall's inequality (see (4.73)), and leveraging the results of Theorem 4.9.

For the property (4.81), a simple computation shows that

$$
\begin{gathered}
\left|J^{\infty}\left(u_{1}^{\circ}\right)-J^{[N]}\left(u_{1}^{\circ}, u_{-1}^{\circ}\right)\right| \leq I_{1}^{N}+I_{2}^{N} \\
I_{1}^{N}=\mathbb{E} \int_{0}^{T}\left|\left|M^{\frac{1}{2}}\left(x_{1}^{\circ}(t)-\widehat{F}_{1} \bar{x}(t)\right)\right|^{2}-\left|M^{\frac{1}{2}}\left(x_{1}^{[N], \circ}(t)-\widehat{F}_{1} x^{(N), \circ}(t)\right)\right|^{2}\right| d t \\
+\mathbb{E}\left|\left|G^{\frac{1}{2}}\left(x_{1}^{\circ}(T)-\widehat{F}_{2} \bar{x}(T)\right)\right|^{2}-\left|G^{\frac{1}{2}}\left(x_{1}^{[N], \circ}(T)-\widehat{F}_{2} x^{(N), \circ}(T)\right)\right|^{2}\right| \\
I_{2}^{N}=\mathbb{E} \int_{0}^{T}\left||K^{-1}(T-t) L(T-t) x_{1}^{\circ}(t)+\tau(t)\right|^{2}-\left|K^{-1}(T-t) L(T-t) x_{1}^{[N], \circ}(t)+\tau(t)\right|^{2} \mid d t
\end{gathered}
$$

where $\tau(t)=K^{-1}(T-t)\left[B^{*} q(T-t)+\Gamma_{2}\left(\left(F_{2} \bar{x}(t)+\sigma\right)^{*} \Pi(T-t)\right)\right]$. For $t \in[0, T)$, we have

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \left|\left|M^{\frac{1}{2}}\left(x_{1}^{\circ}(t)-\widehat{F}_{1} \bar{x}(t)\right)\right|^{2}-\left|M^{\frac{1}{2}}\left(x_{1}^{[N], \circ}(t)-\widehat{F}_{1} x^{(N), \circ}(t)\right)\right|^{2}\right| \\
& \leq\left\|M^{\frac{1}{2}}\left[\left(x_{1}^{\circ}(t)-\widehat{F}_{1} \bar{x}(t)\right)-\left(x_{1}^{[N], \circ}(t)-\widehat{F}_{1} x^{(N), \circ}(t)\right)\right]\right\|^{2} \\
& \quad+2\left|M^{\frac{1}{2}}\left(x_{1}^{\circ}(t)-\widehat{F}_{1} \bar{x}(t)\right)\right|\left|M^{\frac{1}{2}}\left[\left(x_{1}^{\circ}(t)-\widehat{F}_{1} \bar{x}(t)\right)-\left(x_{1}^{[N], \circ}(t)-\widehat{F}_{1} x^{(N), \circ}(t)\right)\right]\right| \\
& \leq 2\left|M^{\frac{1}{2}}\left(x_{1}^{\circ}(t)-x_{1}^{[N], \circ}(t)\right)\right|^{2}+2\left|M^{\frac{1}{2}} \widehat{F}_{1}\left(\bar{x}(t)-x^{(N), \circ}(t)\right)\right|^{2} \\
& \quad+2\left|M^{\frac{1}{2}}\left(x_{1}^{\circ}(t)-\widehat{F}_{1} \bar{x}(t)\right)\right|\left(2\left|M^{\frac{1}{2}}\left(x_{1}^{\circ}(t)-x_{1}^{[N], \circ}(t)\right)\right|^{2}+2\left|M^{\frac{1}{2}} \widehat{F}_{1}\left(\bar{x}(t)-x^{(N), \circ}(t)\right)\right|^{2}\right)^{\frac{1}{2}}
\end{aligned}
$$

We apply the same method to the terminal condition in $I_{1}^{N}$. Then, by using the Cauchy-Schwarz inequality, Theorem 4.9, and Proposition 4.10, we obtain $I_{1}^{N} \leq \frac{C}{\sqrt{N}}$. We employ the same method as above for $I_{2}^{N}$ to obtain $I_{2}^{N} \leq \frac{C}{\sqrt{N}}$.

For the property (4.83), we have

$$
\begin{aligned}
\left|J^{\infty}\left(u_{1}\right)-J^{[N]}\left(u_{1}, u_{-1}^{N}\right)\right| \leq & \mathbb{E} \int_{0}^{T}\left|\left|M^{\frac{1}{2}}\left(x_{1}(t)-\widehat{F}_{1} \bar{x}(t)\right)\right|^{2}-\left|M^{\frac{1}{2}}\left(x_{1}^{[N]}(t)-\widehat{F}_{1} x^{(N)}(t)\right)\right|^{2}\right| d t \\
& +\mathbb{E}\left|\left|G^{\frac{1}{2}}\left(x_{1}(T)-\widehat{F}_{2} \bar{x}(T)\right)\right|^{2}-\left|G^{\frac{1}{2}}\left(x_{1}^{[N]}(T)-\widehat{F}_{2} x^{(N)}(T)\right)\right|^{2}\right|
\end{aligned}
$$

Then we repeat the same method as for the property (4.81) to obtain the property (4.83).
Now, we establish the $\epsilon$-Nash property.

Theorem 4.11. ( $\epsilon$-Nash Equilibrium) Suppose that A4.1 and condition (4.42) hold. Then, the set of control laws $\left\{u_{i}^{\circ}\right\}_{i \in \mathcal{N}}$ where $u_{i}^{\circ}$ is given by (4.51)-(4.52), forms an $\epsilon$-Nash equilibrium for the $N$-player system described by (4.1)-(4.2). That is, for any alternative control action $u_{1} \in \mathcal{U}^{N}$ that the representative agent $i=1$ employs, there is a sequence of nonnegative numbers $\left\{\epsilon_{N}\right\}_{N \in \mathbb{N}}$ converging to zero, such that

$$
J^{[N]}\left(u_{1}^{\circ}, u_{-1}^{\circ}\right) \leq J^{[N]}\left(u_{1}, u_{-1}^{\circ}\right)+\epsilon_{N}
$$

where $\epsilon_{N}=o\left(\frac{1}{\sqrt{N}}\right)$.
Proof. We recall that

$$
J^{\infty}\left(u_{1}^{\circ}\right) \leq J^{\infty}\left(u_{1}\right), \quad \forall u_{1} \in \mathcal{U}^{N}
$$

Then, from (4.81)-(4.83) and (4.91) and we have

$$
J^{[N]}\left(u_{1}^{\circ}, u_{-1}^{\circ}\right)+\frac{C}{\sqrt{N}} \leq J^{\infty}\left(u_{1}^{\circ}\right) \leq J^{\infty}\left(u_{1}\right) \leq J^{[N]}\left(u_{1}, u_{-1}^{\circ}\right)+\frac{C}{\sqrt{N}}
$$

which gives $J^{[N]}\left(u_{1}^{\circ}, u_{-1}^{\circ}\right) \leq J^{[N]}\left(u_{1}, u_{-1}^{\circ}\right)+\frac{C}{\sqrt{N}}$.

# 5. Concluding Remarks 

We conclude the paper by studying a toy model and introducing a slight generalization of our framework that could broaden its applicability.

### 5.1. A Toy Model

We now study a toy model inspired by the model presented in [14], where the dynamics of a representative agent indexed by $i, i \in \mathcal{N}$, is given by

$$
\begin{aligned}
d x_{i}(t) & =\left(A x_{i}(t)+B u_{i}(t)\right) d t+\sigma d W_{i}(t) \\
x_{i}(0) & =\xi
\end{aligned}
$$

Moreover, agent $i$ aims to minimize the cost functional

$$
J^{[N]}\left(u_{i}, u_{-i}\right)=\mathbb{E} \int_{0}^{T}\left(\left|M^{\frac{1}{2}}\left(x_{i}(t)-x^{(N)}(t)\right)\right|^{2}+\left|u_{i}(t)\right|^{2}\right) d t+\mathbb{E}\left|G^{\frac{1}{2}}\left(x_{i}(T)-x^{(N)}(T)\right)\right|^{2}
$$

According to (4.1)-(4.2), we have $F_{1}=F_{2}=D=E=0$, and $\tilde{F}_{1}=\tilde{F}_{2}=I$ for the above model. Applying our results, the contraction condition (4.42) simplifies to

$$
T C_{6} \exp \left(4 T M_{T} C_{6}\right)<1
$$

where $C_{6}=2 M_{T}^{2}\|B\|^{2}(\|G\|+T\|M\|)$. To find a solution for a fixed $T>0$, we can adjust the parameters $G$ and $M$ to ensure that the contraction condition is satisfied. Then the $\epsilon$-Nash equilibrium is given by $\left\{u_{i}^{\circ}\right\}_{i \in \mathcal{N}}$, where

$$
\begin{gathered}
u_{i}^{\circ}(t)=-B^{*}\left(\Pi(T-t) x_{i}(t)+q(T-t)\right) \\
\bar{x}(t)=S(t) \xi-\int_{0}^{t} S(t-r) B^{*}(\Pi(T-t) \bar{x}(t)+q(T-t)) d r \\
\frac{d}{d t}\langle\Pi(t) x, x\rangle=2\langle\Pi(t) x, A x\rangle-\langle\Pi(t) B B^{*} \Pi(t) x, x\rangle+\langle M x, x\rangle \\
\dot{q}(t)=\left(A^{*}-\Pi(t) B B^{*}\right) q(t)-M \bar{x}(T-t)
\end{gathered}
$$

with $\Pi(0)=G, x \in \mathcal{D}(A)$ and $q(0)=-G \bar{x}(T)$.

# 5.2. A Slight Generalization 

Recall that we have defined $D \in \mathcal{L}(H, \mathcal{L}(V, H)), E \in \mathcal{L}(U, \mathcal{L}(V, H)), F_{2} \in \mathcal{L}(H ; \mathcal{L}(V ; H))$, and $\sigma \in \mathcal{L}(V ; H)$ for the volatility in (4.1). As mentioned in Remark 2, this setting might be more restrictive than necessary. One reason for this conservatism is our desire to align, in particular the derivations of Section 4.2.2, with the foundational literature, notably references such as [18] and [43]. These settings could potentially be generalized to bounded linear operators from $H$ and $U$ to $\mathcal{L}_{2}\left(V_{Q}, H\right)$, with $\sigma$ also set as $\sigma \in \mathcal{L}_{2}\left(V_{Q}, H\right)$. The conclusions of this paper could likely be achieved with only minor modifications.

abstract:
This paper presents a comprehensive study of linear-quadratic (LQ) mean field
games (MFGs) in Hilbert spaces, generalizing the classic LQ MFG theory to
scenarios involving $N$ agents with dynamics governed by infinite-dimensional
stochastic equations. In this framework, both state and control processes of
each agent take values in separable Hilbert spaces. All agents are coupled
through the average state of the population which appears in their linear
dynamics and quadratic cost functional. Specifically, the dynamics of each
agent incorporates an infinite-dimensional noise, namely a $Q$-Wiener process,
and an unbounded operator. The diffusion coefficient of each agent is
stochastic involving the state, control, and average state processes. We first
study the well-posedness of a system of $N$ coupled semilinear
infinite-dimensional stochastic evolution equations establishing the foundation
of MFGs in Hilbert spaces. We then specialize to $N$-player LQ games described
above and study the asymptotic behaviour as the number of agents, $N$,
approaches infinity. We develop an infinite-dimensional variant of the Nash
Certainty Equivalence principle and characterize a unique Nash equilibrium for
the limiting MFG. Finally, we study the connections between the $N$-player game
and the limiting MFG, demonstrating that the empirical average state converges
to the mean field and that the resulting limiting best-response strategies form
an $\epsilon$-Nash equilibrium for the $N$-player game in Hilbert spaces.
